Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: ECSS Program Officially Starts
Notes: The U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System (ECSS) is supposed to be a single integrated enterprise resource planning system built using commercial off-the-shelf software, aimed at modernizing the service’s global supply chain. The original estimated life cycle cost of ECSS is put at US $3 billion, with about $1.8 billion allocated to development and $1.2 billion for operations and maintenance. The plan is to fully deploy the system by 2012. After some early replanning exercises to reduce program risk, the project has a “new start” in May 2005. (Note: No one has an authoritative set of financials on ECSS. That was made clear in the U.S. Senate investigation report, which expressed frustration and outrage that the Air Force couldn’t tell it what was spent on what, when it was spent, nor even what ECSS had planned to spend over time. Various reports have conflicting data on estimated and spent costs.)
url: GAO-08-866 Air Force Asset Visibility http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d08866.pdf; GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Major Contract Awarded
Notes:
Computer Sciences Corp. is awarded one of the largest contracts: US $628 million to provide technical and business transformation services. In early 2006, the U.S. Air Force also pays Oracle $90 million to license the software that the system is to be built with.

The intended capabilities of ECSS are still a bit of a mystery. At this time, the Air Force, in two conflicting statements, says that ECSS is going to both replace “more than 400 legacy systems” as well as “over 700 legacy systems.”
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Finances Get Murky
Notes:
The 2008 Government Accountability Office report says that the total life cycle cost of ECSS is still US $3 billion. At the same time, the report also notes that the U.S. Air Force acknowledges that the program is going to overrun that amount, because functionality that was supposed to go into the Defense Enterprise Accounting and Management System (DEAMS) project is now to be merged into ECSS. The number of legacy systems that are going to be replaced starts to drop, with 250 being the number bandied about (although “more than 400 legacy systems” continues to appear in Air Force literature).

The DEAMS project, beginning in 2003, aimed to replace nine Air Force legacy accounting systems at an estimated life cycle cost of $420 million by October 2009. It is now scheduled to be completed in April 2017 at a projected life cycle cost of $2.2 billion.
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Reality Check
Notes: The cost of ECSS has jumped to US $3.4 billion for development, while operations and maintenance stay at about $1.8 billion, and full deployment is slated for 2016 at the earliest. The first piloted release of ECSS has problems with data quality, data conversion, interoperability and integration, usability, information assurance, and requirements testability. As a result, managers decide to restructure not only how the ECSS program is being run but also the system itself. Their aim is to improve data quality, update the Oracle software to be used, and increase the number of releases from three to four.

Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Reassessed
Notes:
In late 2011, the U.S. Air Force and the Office of the Secretary of Defense both conduct reviews of the program and agree that the “development and implementation of ECSS had lagged.”

Spending on the project is now US $876 million, with another $110 million worth of outstanding contract obligations.

Now the Air Force says that ECSS will replace 240 legacy systems.

Program: U.S. Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Canceled
Notes: With ECSS spinning out of control, it is officially canceled at a cost of around US $1.1 billion. The U.S. Air Force admits that it would cost another $1 billion to get just 25 percent of the system’s planned capability. More than $5 billion [PDF] in lost opportunity costs have been incurred as of 2015, and it is likely that at least another $7 billion will be incurred if a replacement is not in place by 2017. At the present time, an ECSS replacement is being planned, but the Air Force isn’t saying how much it will cost, how legacy systems will be replaced, and when it is expected to be operational, although it is promising it will cost less than ECSS. Why did ECSS fail? Three publicly available reports (from IDA [PDF], the Air Force [PDF], and the Senate [PDF]) provide a host of reasons, but management incompetence coupled with excessive hubris and a desire not to hear negative news probably captures 95 percent of it. While promising to learn the lessons from previous similar large-scale IT failures, Air Force management not only studiously ignored them but seemed to willfully defy them. So who is being held accountable for ECSS’s demise? No one, as it turns out. The Air Force’s senior leadership has made it crystal clear that firing or demoting anyone for blowing $1 billion on an absolutely useless IT system is “not necessary.”
url: GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Headline: NCTracks Contract Starts
Notes: North Carolina awards the first contract to Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) for a new Medicaid claims processing and management system called NCTracks. It is the state’s second try, after spending US $30 million on an earlier attempt.

Headline: Project Rescoped, and Schedule Slips
Notes: According to the state auditor, in July 2010 the vendor, CSC, “notified the Department that it would not be able to meet the established go-live date and requested an extension. After lengthy negotiations, the Department approved a contract amendment in July 2011 that granted an 18–22 month extension to build the system, increased the total contract price from US $265 million to $484 million, and extended the operational contract an additional two years to 2020.”

Headline: Increased Delays
Notes: The system is delayed to accommodate legislative and regulatory mandates.

Headline: Premature Launch
Notes:
The system goes live 1 July 2013 and experiences major problems. While it is being developed, North Carolina spends at least US $36 million (net) to keep its legacy benefits system going because of the delay.

Medicaid certification is expected for summer 2014, but that doesn’t happen until March 2015 because of extensive bugs in the system. NCTracks really can’t be considered “fixed” until March 2015, which is when it receives federal certification.

Headline: Project Officially Starts
Notes: The Disability Insurance Automation project aims to automate a number of manual work processes involved when filing for a disability insurance claim.

Headline: Project Rescoped
Notes: Procurement issues cause the schedule to slip, but the project cost is reduced.

Headline: Project Reassessed and Reset
Notes: California’s Employment Development Department recognizes that it underestimated the complexity and effort required to create the system, so the project is rescoped. Deloitte Consulting will be paid US $52 million to build the system. Development now begins in earnest.

Headline: Project Scope Changed
Notes:
Changes in the project’s scope increase life cycle costs and delay the schedule. Development costs climb another US $8 million.

A state legislative report from May 2012 attributed the higher price tag to “costs that often accrue over the life span of a project, including increased state staffing needs, enhanced system functionality or scope increases, and data center costs, among other things.”

Headline: System Launches Early
Notes:
The system launches “ahead of schedule,” but there are several months of working through frustrating transition issues.

It is clear that the total development cost will be more than US $60 million if we include the state’s incurred costs, but we don’t know those costs because the details of the total amount spent on the project aren’t broken out in any audit report.

Headline: California’s Unemployment Insurance Modernization Project Officially Starts
Notes:
California’s Employment Development Department (EDD) originally plans two system developments. The Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade (CCNPAU) is meant to create a single networked infrastructure for EDD’s call centers that will interact with an intelligent call routing system. The Continued Claims Redesign (CCR) is intended to develop a website and a telephone application that will allow customers to file unemployment insurance claims and to recertify on a biweekly basis by Internet or phone.

The Call Center project is targeted for completion in 2006. The Continued Claims Redesign effort had a larger budget and timeline.

Headline: California’s Unemployment Insurance Modernization Project Officially Starts
Notes:
California’s Employment Development Department (EDD) originally plans two system developments. The Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade (CCNPAU) is meant to create a single networked infrastructure for EDD’s call centers that will interact with an intelligent call routing system. The Continued Claims Redesign (CCR) is intended to develop a website and a telephone application that will allow customers to file unemployment insurance claims and to recertify on a biweekly basis by Internet or phone.

The Call Center project is targeted for completion in 2006. The Continued Claims Redesign effort had a larger budget and timeline.

Headline: Projects Merge
Notes: Only a few months ahead of CCNPAU’s original completion date, both projects are merged into one due to multiple interdependencies. From what IEEE Spectrum has pieced together, nothing much has happened during the intervening three years. One document says that a project planning phase started in July 2005 and ran into 2006. What happened in 2004 seems to be a mystery. The merged projects maintain separate schedules. CCNPAU completion is pushed back four years, longer than the initial scheduled development time. CCR also receives an increased estimate and a delayed launch date.

Headline: Projects Merge
Notes: Only a few months ahead of CCNPAU’s original completion date, both projects are merged into one due to multiple interdependencies. From what IEEE Spectrum has pieced together, nothing much has happened during the intervening three years. One document says that a project planning phase started in July 2005 and ran into 2006. What happened in 2004 seems to be a mystery. The merged projects maintain separate schedules. CCNPAU completion is pushed back four years, longer than the initial scheduled development time. CCR also receives an increased estimate and a delayed launch date.

Headline: Project Costs Increase
Notes: Due to changes in the procurement approach, the cost of CCNPAU rises yet again, but the timeline is optimistically reduced. Meanwhile, CCR costs and delays continue to mount.

Headline: Project Costs Increase
Notes: Due to changes in the procurement approach, the cost of CCNPAU rises yet again, but the timeline is optimistically reduced. Meanwhile, CCR costs and delays continue to mount.

Headline: More Cost Increases and Delays
Notes: Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays are growing again. But now CCR sees a schedule reduction! (The completion date is only moved up a single month, however.)

Headline: More Cost Increases and Delays
Notes: Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays are growing again. But now CCR sees a schedule reduction! (The completion date is only moved up a single month, however.)

Headline: Call Center Upgrade Launches
Notes: CCNPAU rolls out in May 2011, missing its 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by more than four years). It isn’t a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times are rampant.

Headline: More Delays
Notes: CCR’s launch is delayed by another year.

Headline: Claims Redesign System Launches
Notes: CCR is rolled out over Labor Day weekend, also four months off its final deadline (but more than five years late, according to the original schedule). What’s more, the launch is a total disaster. Since launch, the state has spent approximately US $4 million on upgrading and fixing CCR.

Headline: IBM Wins Contract for Queensland Health’s Payroll Replacement System
Notes:
IBM is awarded a AU $98 million Shared Services Initiative (SSI) contract to provide statewide human resources and financial solutions in Queensland, Australia.

A small portion of this contract, AU $6.19 million, is budgeted for creating a new payroll system at Queensland Health. Considering that the state has already tried (and failed) to build such a system before, it should be aware that this is an impossibly low estimate.

Headline: Nothing Delivered Yet
Notes: Six months in, an auditor would later note, nothing of consequence has been delivered. There’s a slight increase in project cost and schedule.

Headline: Focus Now on Payroll
Notes:
The payroll system is still not close to being completed. IBM now says that the cost to provide statewide human resources and a financial solution for Queensland Health is now AU $181 million. That’s too much, so the larger initiative is scrapped.

Instead, the new focus will be on getting the Queensland Health payroll system to work. IBM has already spent a total of AU $32 million of its AU $98 million contract, including monies spent on the payroll system.

A total reassessment of the project should have been made, and a new project cost and schedule calculated just to do the payroll system. But this wasn’t done. The payroll system development—intended to be a quick, low-cost solution—spiraled totally out of control.

A late November 2008 go-live-date was anticipated, but this was soon reset for the March/April 2009 timeframe. This would prove hopelessly optimistic as well.

Headline: System Launches Prematurely
Notes:
There was a lot of work during the next year, but little progress, and the deployment schedule slipped muliple times. The major problem is the complexity of the labor contracts and labor categories involved. There are reportedly 24,000 different ways the staff can be paid, based on 13 different award structures and 13 labor agreements. The schedule slips were generally due to the project’s failure to stabilize the system sufficiently to pass tests.

According to a later inquiry report, “On 14 March 2010 after ten aborted attempts to deliver the new payroll system, it ‘went live.’ It was a catastrophic failure…”

When the system (still not fully tested) goes live, the effects are disastrous: more than 18,000 staff affected, with 1,800 not paid or underpaid. The total staff numbers 78,000. Many employees get the correct pay one pay period but not the next. The total number of affected staff who had at least one pay period screwed up is unknown. In total, there are AU $14.5 million in salary glitches.

IBM’s cost for payroll system now is AU $25 million (it has been paid AU $22 million); the government says that the total cost of the payroll system, including its own expenditures, amounts to $102 million.

Headline: Time to Go All-in
Notes: The government decides to spend another AU $209 million to try to fix the system.

Headline: System Relaunches
Notes: The government claims that the payroll system is stabilized.

Headline: Not Over Yet
Notes:
At least AU $440 million will be spent on developing the system. Up to another AU $100 million may be needed to fix the system completely, while AU $837 million will be needed to operate it for the next five years; AU $91 million in salary overpayments are still outstanding. The total life cycle cost is at least AU $1.25 billion. As of 31 May 2012, 200,000 processes were still being performed manually on 92,000 forms every two-week pay period by more than 1,000 Queensland Health payroll employees. In order to make it work, the payroll system needs thousands of modifications and customizations, with some 130 manual workarounds being employed.

Some AU $5 million has been spent by the inquiry that was set up to try to make sense of what happened.

Headline: FiReControl Project Start
Notes:
FiReControl aims to replace 46 local control rooms with a network of nine purpose-built regional control centers, which will use a national computer system to handle calls, mobilize equipment, and manage incidents. Initial rollout is due in October 2007, with a final rollout scheduled for October 2009.

Project costs include both IT and facility construction costs, since neither can operate without the other.

Headline: Reality Creeps In
Notes: By February 2006, the people involved begin to realize that the project has been severely underestimated in both size and complexity—especially the information technology required. The FiReControl project is reassessed, and a new estimate of £340 million is published. The European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (EADS) is hired as the prime contractor in March 2007 to develop the IT system required; the contract could be worth up to £200 million over eight years. The initial rollout is now set for October 2009, with a final completion date set for end of 2011.

Headline: Reality Bites Hard
Notes: The project is poorly managed, with little government oversight. In April 2008, EADS admits that the technology needed to develop a critical element of the system is no longer working. Fully operational system is now set for early 2012.

Headline: Project Problems Abound
Notes: The project cost stays the same, but the schedule drifts. A major review discovers ineffective project management, poor project planning, and poor working relationships between suppliers and the government.

Headline: Project Terminated
Notes: Project is terminated after £250 million has been spent. There’s another £219 million in already committed costs, bumping the total spending to £469 million. The final “estimated” cost to complete at FiReControl’s termination had grown to £635 million, with a rollout beginning sometime in 2012 and going through who knows when.
